Body:
BC-BJT0716-SUNDAY-4THLEDE-COX 
    

      4TH LEDE
      Deletes: PRISON
      
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR SUNDAY, July 16, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   THE WEEKEND DUTY EDITORS ARE:

   IN ATLANTA: Diane Fall at 404-526-7282

   IN WASHINGTON: Elliot Jaspin at 703-725-7031 (cell phone)

   NATION

   GORE-DLC _ BALTIMORE - The Democratic Leadership Council, which
represents the centrist wing of the Democratic Party is clearly in
control, with one of the DLC's founders, Vice President Al Gore,
preparing to accept the party's presidential nomination. Gore
addresses the DLC on Saturday, capping the organization's two-day
conference. (Shepard, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   TECH-DIVERSITY _ BOSTON _ The business attire has changed from
stuffy suits to casual cool, but the faces remain largely the same.
The New Economy, like the old economy, is dominated by white males.
High-tech professions have a disproportionately small number of
women, blacks and Hispanics in high-paying technical jobs. The
pipeline of science and math majors from American colleges and
universities suggests that the situation will not soon improve,
leaving the specter of a growing wage gap. (Holmes, Cox News
Service).

   WITH PHOTOS.

   MOVED Thursday on NYT wire in (a) national and (f) financial
categories

   GRASSPEA _ WASHINGTON _ A small dryland pea that often saves the
world's poorest people from starvation _ and then leaves thousands
paralyzed for life _ has been genetically changed to eliminate its
crippling trait. (Nesmith, Cox News Service) WITH PHOTO.

   MOVED Monday.

   GUN-LICENSING _ WASHINGTON _ One of the goals of the Million Mom
March is widely seen as unattainable _ licensing gun owners much as
we do drivers and hair stylists. A look at why some people see
licensing as a key to reducing gun violence, and others as a danger
to liberty. (Moscoso, Cox News Service).

   MOVING Thursday.

   INTERNET-POLITICS _ WASHINGTON _ The Internet tidal wave is
bearing down on the venerable institution of political conventions.
As traditional TV and print coverage has waned, more than 100
dot-com news organizations are moving in, some planning a major
presence with skyboxes and celebrity anchors. (Glass, Cox News
Service).

   MOVED Monday in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   CLINTON _ WASHINGTON _ At President Clinton's last Group of
Seven (plus Russia) summit meeting, what does the lame-duck leader
hope to accomplish? He is still the big dog in this yard, but is
also leaving office soon. Is there anything that he can influence?
Are his partners already beginning to look past him? Developing.
(Deans, Cox News Service).

   With issues box attached.

   Expected to move in advance on the NYT Wire in both
International/Commentary categories.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   INTERNATIONAL

   BRITAIN-MUM _ LONDON _ The Queen Mum, Queen Elizabeth's mother,
turns 100 on Aug. 4 and will be honored with a gala. The old gal is
still knocking back the gin and raising hell in Buckingham Palace.
Developing. (Roughton, Cox News Service).

   MOVED Wed., July 12, in both International/Lifestyle categories.

   COX-NIRELAND-PEACE _ BELFAST, Northern Ireland _ The marching
season ends with far more violence and tension than anyone expected
, or wanted. How will this season's problems affect the Northern
Ireland peace negotiations? Developing. (Roughton, Cox News
Service).

   MOVED Fri., July 14.

   (Eds. This is the CoxNet Focus page for the week. The layout is
now available)

   COXNET FOCUS 0716: CLASSIC CARS, ANCIENT CITY _ The names come
out a little differently in Arabic. DeSoto becomes something like
``Tozata'' and Chrysler sounds like ``Kleezler.'' But those old
bombs you might find in an auto collector's garage in America make
for colorful and practical transportation in Syria. The country's
streets are flush with fins and crawling with chrome. Stroll the
centuries-old bazaars and you're likely to be passed not only your
father's Oldsmobile, but his father's before him. (Kaplow, Cox
Washington Bureau). Art includes a 3-column color photo of a
classic car sitting in a garage, a 2-column detail shot of a car, a
3-column photo of a Syrian in front of his car and a 2-column color
photo of a Syrian working on his car.

   BUSINESS

   UPS _ The drivers of those chocolate brown trucks with gold trim
are known for moving packages at the ``speed of business'' from one
door to another. But the nation's largest parcel delivery service
is finding that moving packages is a lot easier than moving
Washington. ``Big Brown,'' as the company is commonly called, is
vying for a lucrative air route to China against another
Atlanta-based powerhouse, Delta Air Lines, as well as American
Airlines and Polar Air Cargo, an upstart freight carrier based in
California. (Carr, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   WITH

   UPS-PYNE _ Joe Pyne, head of UPS's new e-commerce venture, is
the epitome of the United Parcel Service leader. Like ``98
percent'' of the top brass at UPS, Pyne began working part-time as
a truck loader for the company during the late 1960s to help pay
for his college education. (Poe, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED.

   WITH

   UPS-POSTAL _ Last spring, United Parcel Service drivers
descended on Capitol Hill to make an important delivery for their
company: chocolate brown corrugated boxes filled with materials
attacking the U.S. Postal Service. Every member of the House got
one of the computer laptop-sized boxes. Tucked inside was a slick
CD entitled, ``What The Postal Service Doesn't Want You to Know.''
There were also negative news articles and a 16-page booklet that
compared the postal service to the CIA. (Carr, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ There was more chutzpah than healing in George
W. Bush's speech to the national convention of the NAACP. Credit
the Republican presidential candidate with trying. No GOP
nominee-presumptive has bothered visiting the convention since 1988
when Bush's father addressed it. (Tom Teepen is national
correspondent for Cox Newspapers.) MOVED THURSDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ Howard Kleinberg says that if protests get
out of hand at this summer's political conventions, police in the
host cities should take a cue from the ``interesting'' ways in
which Miami Beach Police Chief Rocky Pomerance handled matters at
Republican conventions held there in 1968 and 1972. (Kleinberg, Cox
News Service.) MOVED THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ (Andy Glass is a columnist for Cox News Service
in the Washington bureau.) MOVED THURSDAY.

   LIFESTYLE

   CREMATION _ ``It's an irreversible decision,'' Chet Robbins
advises me. Well, yes. To stretch this body out and bake it for two
hours at 1600 degrees reduces my decision-making powers, and me, to
about 4 pounds of crumbled bone. There goes the figure-skating
career... At the subject of cremation even Robbins, who as
executive director of the Texas Funeral Service Commission should
be used to this type of thing by now, clicks off the joviality and
turns a dour, professional gray. It wasn't so long ago, he says,
``People would have asked, `What's cremation?' '' Traditional
funerals, with embalming, caskets, religious services, and ground
burial in a family plot, weren't really matters of choice. They
were the rule. Not so today. More and more people are choosing to
be cremated at death. (Ardery, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   COXNET HEALTHY LIVING _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Healthy Living
page for the current week. This layout is now available.)

   CoxNet HEALTHY LIVING 0715: THE BRITTLE ENEMY _ In medical
terms, osteoporosis is the disease resulting from reduced bone
density that leads to increased susceptibility of fractures. Family
history is the biggest risk factor, and the biggest predictor of
osteoporosis, experts say. But new screening and drugs can now
prevent the disease, even in women who have inherited ``bad bones.
(Guthrie, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column
color illustration of a woman's bones and a 1-column color
illustration of healthy and porous bones.

   WITH: OSTEOPOROSIS Q&A _ Answers to some frequently asked
questions about osteoporosis. Art includes a 18-pica color photo of
a woman having her heel scanned for osteoporosis.

   WITH: OSTEOPOROSIS INFO BOX _ Where to turn for more information
about osteoporosis.

   WITH: YOUR HEALTH _ Summer is a time when children are more at
risk of having their teeth knocked out. Here's what you should do
if a child loses a tooth. (Lore, Atlanta Journal Constitution)

   WITH: HEALTH & MEDIA _ The American Council for Exercise, a
nonprofit organization, has endorsed a diet book for the first
time. (Coyle, Atlanta Journal Constitution) Art includes a 1-column
color photo of book jacket.

   WITH: ON THE WEB _ A sex quiz helps you determine if your online
behavior is putting you at risk. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal
Constitution) Art includes a 6-pica color illustration of a
computer.

   COXNET LIFESTYLES_ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Lifestyles page for
the current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES 0715: KEEPING IT GREEN: This summer you're
determined to keep your grass green no matter what extremes Mother
Nature dishes out. Neither temperatures in the triple digits nor
weeks without rain will prevent you from having a lush lawn that
will be the envy of all your neighbors. (Flanders, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes eight 2-column color photos of
ways to keep your lawn green during the summer.

   WITH: LAWN TIPS _ Additional tips to make sure your yard stays
green and healthy.

   WITH: PAINT JOB _ Painting takes so much work that it's a good
idea to do it right and get the most years possible out of the job.
(Cumming, Dayton Daily News) Art includes a 18-pica color photo of
a man using a paint roller.

   CLERGY _ Denominations are struggling to find clergy to serve
rural churches. They either don't have enough, assign elderly
pastors, or accept young pastors with less than stellar
credentials. Most are old or non-existent and this has fueled the
communions between churches, such as the Lutherans and
Episcopalians, because they can now share clergy. (Perkes, Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   INFECTION _ The largest international conference on threats from
infectious disease, sponsored every two years by the CDC, opens
this evening in Atlanta. Major topics to be discussed include: the
growing problem of antibiotic resistance, the danger of unpredicted
problems such as West Nile virus, the likelihood of disease
organisms being used as weapons, and the influence of climate
change and major population movements on the development of
diseases. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   PANO-BOYS _ Niko and Pano Karatassos are the future of the
Buckhead Life Restaurant Group. These two young men _ a manager and
a chef _ will one day be the heart, the brains and the soul of this
business that their father, Pano Karatassos, grew in 20 years from
a single white-tablecloth restaurant, Pano's and Paul's. Now with
its diverse roster of 10 brand-name eateries _ including Buckhead
Diner, Atlanta Fish Market and Chops _ Buckhead Life is one of the
top fine-dining restaurant groups in the country. It realized more
than $68 million in sales in 1999 and ranked among the top 100
privately owned companies in Georgia. Yet even as the company
stakes its future on reproducing successful brands, its two sons
may try and push it to the next level. Before they consider taking
over their dad's company, Niko and Pano Karatassos want to open a
place together. And it won't be like anything Buckhead Life has
seen before. (Kessler, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TRAVEL

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET TRAVEL 0715: CAPTURING YOSEMITE _ Camera walks focus on
capturing Yosemite National Park's staggering vistas that inspired
the monumental images created by America's greatest nature
photographer (Meyers, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a
3-column color photo of El Capitan.

   WITH: TO DO BOX _ A list of thing to do when visiting Yosemite
National Park.

   WITH: TAKING PICTURES _ Here are some tips from professional
photographers on how to take great vacation pictures. (O'Brien,
Waco Herald-Tribune) Art includes two 2-column color photos
illustrating how to compose a photograph.

   WITH: TRAVEL BRIEFS _ Higher prices are forecast for business
travelers. Others. (N.Y. Times News Service)

   BROOKLYN _ BROOKLYN, N.Y. _ It wasn't until I plopped down in a
booth at Junior's _ the sprawling, orange-vinyl delicatessen run by
the Rosen family for more than 50 years at the corner of Flatbush
and DeKalb avenues _ that I began to realize what a melting pot New
York's most populous borough is. In Brooklyn, habitat of Hassids
and homeboys, matzah ball soup is served side by side with collard
greens and salmon croquettes. Over a recent long weekend, I didn't
have nearly enough time to eat my way around this ethnic-food
lover's paradise. But I did hopscotch around sufficiently to see
why it's New York's new ground zero of cool, why trendies from
``The City'' are subwaying over to check out the clubs and
restaurants, the museums and green spaces, the Gothic architecture
and Gotham views. (Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) WITH
PHOTOS. MOVED.

   WITH

   BROOKLYNTOUR _ Brooklyn, N.Y. _ Brooklyn proves to be an ideal
place for a weekend's sight-seeing. Another option, of course, is
to stay in Manhattan and take a day trip to the Second City, only
30 minutes away by subway. Just take your walking shoes, and don't
plan on hurrying back after dark. We give highlights of a recent
visit.(Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   BROOKLYN-LIST _ Robert Spano, the new music director of the
Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and the conductor of the Brooklyn
Philharmonic since 1996, tells us his four favorite things to do in
the borough.(Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED.

   VANGOGH _ BOSTON _ Taking a look at ``Van Gogh: Face to Face,''
on view at the Museum of Fine Arts here through Sept. 24. This is
the only East Coast stop for this touring exhibit, the first to
focus solely on Van Gogh's portraiture. There are more than 70
works on view, including several haunting self-portraits. For those
getting excited about the High Museum's mini Van Gogh exhibit
coming September, this show tempts a summer visit to Beantown.
(BLongino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   FASHION

   FASHION-CHEAPTHRILLS _ What fashionable finds are there to buy
on a budget of $100? Three stylemaking ladies let us know as they
shop Kmart, Target and Walmart and bring back the goods. (Hill,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   BOOKS

   COXNET BOOKS _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Books page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)COXNET BOOKS 0715:
AMAZON'S GUIDE _ a suburban Atlanta housewife has become the
favorite reviewer for the Amazon.com Web site. She reads books as
regularly as most people brush their teeth, one in the morning and
one at night, and for the past five years she has written more than
500 reviews for Amazon.com. (O'Briant, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo of the
reviewer.

   WITH: READING LIST _ A list of summer reading from Amazon.com's
top reviewer. Art includes a 6-pica color photo of a book jacket.

   WITH: MISTRESS _ in ``Marrying the Mistress,'' British novelist
Joanna Trollope thrives on casting a literate light on the domestic
circumstances of ordinary people. (Nizzi Warmbold, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 6-pica color photo of a book
jacket.

   WITH: AMIS _ The many surprises in Martin Amis' ``Experience''
include his discovery that he fathered a daughter during a long-ago
affair, and the eventual revelation of what befell a cousin who
disappeared in 1973. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art
includes a 6-pica color photo of book jacket.

   WITH: BOOK NOTES _ ``White Oleander'' author finds life much
different after Oprah's touch. (O'Briant, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SIDDONS _ A Q&A with Anne Rivers Siddons, whose new book ``Nora,
Nora,'' set in a small Georgia town, comes out July 18. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   REVIEW_ROSE _ Review of Tananarive Due's novel ``The Black
Rose,'' a fictionalized version of the life of Madam C.J. Walker,
the first black female millionaire. Boyd, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   SKUBE-ON-BOOKS _ The mystery novel depends on its contrivances
of character and setting, and more often than not is the better for
it. A familiar world doesn't have to be a believable world. It's
enough that a reader return, suspending reality and living in a
world he knows intimately. In only two novels, Ace Atkins has
learned how to use the devices so adeptly you hardly notice them.
At the same time, he has created a character, Nick Travers, we want
to know better. (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   SPORTS

   BRITISH OPEN COVERAGE

   BRITISH _ The Old Course: It is said to be one of the most
beautiful venues in golf. No island greens; no doctored doglegs; no
tricked-up, pitch-and-putt holes. Instead, the natural setting for
St. Andrews remains as it was when the course was constructed back
in the old days. Yes, you sometimes must hit your tee shot over a
boarding house. And yes, you might have to hit off a gravel road.
And those are just two of the reasons the 2000 British Open will
offer challenges to the best golf has to offer. (Sheeley) 25''
MOVED.

   WITH

   BRITISH-HOLE _ A look at six of the most unusual holes at the
British Open. (Sheeley, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED. WITH

   BRITISH-SIDE _ At the point of being redundant, St. Andrews fits
Tiger Woods like a glove. (Sheeley, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED.

   Eds. Coxnet will produce a BRITISH OPEN PREVIEW PAGE that will
available on Friday, July 14 by 5 p.m.

   The page will include some of these elements.

   FOOTBALL

   PROS

   FBN-FALCONS _ Lede story TBA from Falcons training camp.
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 18''

   FBN-COWBOYS _ Top 10 questions about the Cowboys heading into
camp. (Cantu, Austin American-Statesman)

   OLYMPICS

   OLYRUN _ Coverage of the second day of the Olympic Track and
field Trials in Sacramento, California. ( Maher, Austin
American-Statesman)

   RACING

   COXNET NASCAR PAGE STILL AVAILABLE

   This week's Inside NASCAR page can be found via the Budget Tool
using the Sports category and a Motorsports subcategory with a
rundate of Friday. The page can also be found on the Cox Server in
the Sports folder and on the WAN desk of the AJC database. For
questions, call CoxNet at (404) 526-5456 Note: This is an off-week
for Winston Cup. Following is a budget for the page:

   COXNET INSIDE NASCAR 0714: STICKING THROTTLE _ Drivers think
NASCAR needs to approve a button that would allow engines to be cut
off in cases where throttles stick. It appears stuck throttles
contibuted to the deaths of drivers Adam Petty and Kenny Irwin.
Other racing circuits have ``escape'' buttons when these incidents
happen. (Minter, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   WITH

   NASCAR IMAGE _ NASCAR drivers say they aren't ready for
sainthood, but they have been able to avoid the bad headlines
created by athletes in other sports. (Carvell, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   DRIVER STANDINGS WINSTON CUP

   DRIVER STANDINGS BUSCH SERIES

   WINSTON CUP MONEY LEADERS

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves daily through the week, then on Saturday at 2
p.m. and 6 p.m. EST and afterwards as necessary based on news
developments. If stories will move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be
given. All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   The day news editor is Tom Oder, 404-526-5887,
toder(at)coxnews.com.

   The night news editor is Todd C. Duncan, 404-582-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com.

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
Text:
For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   With issues box attached.

   Expected to move in advance on the NYT Wire in both
International/Commentary categories.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   INTERNATIONAL

turns 100 on Aug. 4 and will be honored with a gala. The old gal is
still knocking back the gin and raising hell in Buckingham Palace.
Developing. (Roughton, Cox News Service).

   MOVED Wed., July 12, in both International/Lifestyle categories.

   COX-NIRELAND-PEACE _ BELFAST, Northern Ireland _ The marching
season ends with far more violence and tension than anyone expected

Ireland peace negotiations? Developing. (Roughton, Cox News
Service).

   MOVED Fri., July 14.

   (Eds. This is the CoxNet Focus page for the week. The layout is
now available)

photo of a Syrian working on his car.

in the Washington bureau.) MOVED THURSDAY.

   COXNET HEALTHY LIVING _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Healthy Living
page for the current week. This layout is now available.)

   CoxNet HEALTHY LIVING 0715: THE BRITTLE ENEMY _ In medical
terms, osteoporosis is the disease resulting from reduced bone
density that leads to increased susceptibility of fractures. Family
history is the biggest risk factor, and the biggest predictor of
osteoporosis, experts say. But new screening and drugs can now
prevent the disease, even in women who have inherited ``bad bones.
(Guthrie, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column
color illustration of a woman's bones and a 1-column color
illustration of healthy and porous bones.

   WITH: OSTEOPOROSIS Q&A _ Answers to some frequently asked
questions about osteoporosis. Art includes a 18-pica color photo of
a woman having her heel scanned for osteoporosis.

   WITH: OSTEOPOROSIS INFO BOX _ Where to turn for more information
about osteoporosis.

   WITH: YOUR HEALTH _ Summer is a time when children are more at
risk of having their teeth knocked out. Here's what you should do
if a child loses a tooth. (Lore, Atlanta Journal Constitution)

   WITH: HEALTH & MEDIA _ The American Council for Exercise, a
nonprofit organization, has endorsed a diet book for the first
time. (Coyle, Atlanta Journal Constitution) Art includes a 1-column
color photo of book jacket.

   WITH: ON THE WEB _ A sex quiz helps you determine if your online
behavior is putting you at risk. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal
Constitution) Art includes a 6-pica color illustration of a
computer.

   COXNET LIFESTYLES_ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Lifestyles page for
the current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES 0715: KEEPING IT GREEN: This summer you're
determined to keep your grass green no matter what extremes Mother
Nature dishes out. Neither temperatures in the triple digits nor
weeks without rain will prevent you from having a lush lawn that
will be the envy of all your neighbors. (Flanders, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes eight 2-column color photos of
ways to keep your lawn green during the summer.

   WITH: LAWN TIPS _ Additional tips to make sure your yard stays
green and healthy.

   WITH: PAINT JOB _ Painting takes so much work that it's a good
idea to do it right and get the most years possible out of the job.
(Cumming, Dayton Daily News) Art includes a 18-pica color photo of
a man using a paint roller.

   CLERGY _ Denominations are struggling to find clergy to serve
rural churches. They either don't have enough, assign elderly
pastors, or accept young pastors with less than stellar
credentials. Most are old or non-existent and this has fueled the
communions between churches, such as the Lutherans and
Episcopalians, because they can now share clergy. (Perkes, Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   INFECTION _ The largest international conference on threats from
infectious disease, sponsored every two years by the CDC, opens
this evening in Atlanta. Major topics to be discussed include: the
growing problem of antibiotic resistance, the danger of unpredicted
problems such as West Nile virus, the likelihood of disease
organisms being used as weapons, and the influence of climate
change and major population movements on the development of
diseases. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   PANO-BOYS _ Niko and Pano Karatassos are the future of the
Buckhead Life Restaurant Group. These two young men _ a manager and
a chef _ will one day be the heart, the brains and the soul of this
business that their father, Pano Karatassos, grew in 20 years from
a single white-tablecloth restaurant, Pano's and Paul's. Now with
its diverse roster of 10 brand-name eateries _ including Buckhead
Diner, Atlanta Fish Market and Chops _ Buckhead Life is one of the
top fine-dining restaurant groups in the country. It realized more
than $68 million in sales in 1999 and ranked among the top 100
privately owned companies in Georgia. Yet even as the company
stakes its future on reproducing successful brands, its two sons
may try and push it to the next level. Before they consider taking
over their dad's company, Niko and Pano Karatassos want to open a
place together. And it won't be like anything Buckhead Life has
seen before. (Kessler, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TRAVEL

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET TRAVEL 0715: CAPTURING YOSEMITE _ Camera walks focus on
capturing Yosemite National Park's staggering vistas that inspired
the monumental images created by America's greatest nature
photographer (Meyers, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a
3-column color photo of El Capitan.

   WITH: TO DO BOX _ A list of thing to do when visiting Yosemite
National Park.

   WITH: TAKING PICTURES _ Here are some tips from professional
photographers on how to take great vacation pictures. (O'Brien,
Waco Herald-Tribune) Art includes two 2-column color photos
illustrating how to compose a photograph.

   WITH: TRAVEL BRIEFS _ Higher prices are forecast for business
travelers. Others. (N.Y. Times News Service)

   BROOKLYN _ BROOKLYN, N.Y. _ It wasn't until I plopped down in a
booth at Junior's _ the sprawling, orange-vinyl delicatessen run by
the Rosen family for more than 50 years at the corner of Flatbush
and DeKalb avenues _ that I began to realize what a melting pot New
York's most populous borough is. In Brooklyn, habitat of Hassids
and homeboys, matzah ball soup is served side by side with collard
greens and salmon croquettes. Over a recent long weekend, I didn't
have nearly enough time to eat my way around this ethnic-food
lover's paradise. But I did hopscotch around sufficiently to see
why it's New York's new ground zero of cool, why trendies from
``The City'' are subwaying over to check out the clubs and
restaurants, the museums and green spaces, the Gothic architecture
and Gotham views. (Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) WITH
PHOTOS. MOVED.

   WITH

   BROOKLYNTOUR _ Brooklyn, N.Y. _ Brooklyn proves to be an ideal
place for a weekend's sight-seeing. Another option, of course, is
to stay in Manhattan and take a day trip to the Second City, only
30 minutes away by subway. Just take your walking shoes, and don't
plan on hurrying back after dark. We give highlights of a recent
visit.(Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   BROOKLYN-LIST _ Robert Spano, the new music director of the
Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and the conductor of the Brooklyn
Philharmonic since 1996, tells us his four favorite things to do in
the borough.(Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED.

   VANGOGH _ BOSTON _ Taking a look at ``Van Gogh: Face to Face,''
on view at the Museum of Fine Arts here through Sept. 24. This is
the only East Coast stop for this touring exhibit, the first to
focus solely on Van Gogh's portraiture. There are more than 70
works on view, including several haunting self-portraits. For those
getting excited about the High Museum's mini Van Gogh exhibit
coming September, this show tempts a summer visit to Beantown.
(BLongino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   FASHION

   FASHION-CHEAPTHRILLS _ What fashionable finds are there to buy
on a budget of $100? Three stylemaking ladies let us know as they
shop Kmart, Target and Walmart and bring back the goods. (Hill,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   BOOKS

   COXNET BOOKS _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Books page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)COXNET BOOKS 0715:
AMAZON'S GUIDE _ a suburban Atlanta housewife has become the
favorite reviewer for the Amazon.com Web site. She reads books as
regularly as most people brush their teeth, one in the morning and
one at night, and for the past five years she has written more than
500 reviews for Amazon.com. (O'Briant, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo of the
reviewer.

   WITH: READING LIST _ A list of summer reading from Amazon.com's
top reviewer. Art includes a 6-pica color photo of a book jacket.

   WITH: MISTRESS _ in ``Marrying the Mistress,'' British novelist
Joanna Trollope thrives on casting a literate light on the domestic
circumstances of ordinary people. (Nizzi Warmbold, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 6-pica color photo of a book
jacket.

   WITH: AMIS _ The many surprises in Martin Amis' ``Experience''
include his discovery that he fathered a daughter during a long-ago
affair, and the eventual revelation of what befell a cousin who
disappeared in 1973. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art
includes a 6-pica color photo of book jacket.

   WITH: BOOK NOTES _ ``White Oleander'' author finds life much
different after Oprah's touch. (O'Briant, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SIDDONS _ A Q&A with Anne Rivers Siddons, whose new book ``Nora,
Nora,'' set in a small Georgia town, comes out July 18. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   REVIEW_ROSE _ Review of Tananarive Due's novel ``The Black
Rose,'' a fictionalized version of the life of Madam C.J. Walker,
the first black female millionaire. Boyd, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   SKUBE-ON-BOOKS _ The mystery novel depends on its contrivances
of character and setting, and more often than not is the better for
it. A familiar world doesn't have to be a believable world. It's
enough that a reader return, suspending reality and living in a
world he knows intimately. In only two novels, Ace Atkins has
learned how to use the devices so adeptly you hardly notice them.
At the same time, he has created a character, Nick Travers, we want
to know better. (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   SPORTS

   BRITISH OPEN COVERAGE

   BRITISH _ The Old Course: It is said to be one of the most
beautiful venues in golf. No island greens; no doctored doglegs; no
tricked-up, pitch-and-putt holes. Instead, the natural setting for
St. Andrews remains as it was when the course was constructed back
in the old days. Yes, you sometimes must hit your tee shot over a
boarding house. And yes, you might have to hit off a gravel road.
And those are just two of the reasons the 2000 British Open will
offer challenges to the best golf has to offer. (Sheeley) 25''
MOVED.

   WITH

   BRITISH-HOLE _ A look at six of the most unusual holes at the
British Open. (Sheeley, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED. WITH

   BRITISH-SIDE _ At the point of being redundant, St. Andrews fits
Tiger Woods like a glove. (Sheeley, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED.

   COXNET INSIDE NASCAR 0714: STICKING THROTTLE _ Drivers think
NASCAR needs to approve a button that would allow engines to be cut
off in cases where throttles stick. It appears stuck throttles
contibuted to the deaths of drivers Adam Petty and Kenny Irwin.
Other racing circuits have ``escape'' buttons when these incidents
happen. (Minter, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   WITH

   NASCAR IMAGE _ NASCAR drivers say they aren't ready for
sainthood, but they have been able to avoid the bad headlines
created by athletes in other sports. (Carvell, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).
